content.description:
The second most popular route at Mt Tammany, with several variations.

 Start 4 feet left of the big block with the tree on top of it. 

Pitch 1: Climb up over the vegetated ledges to the blocky wall above. Climb toward a short chimney, through the chimney and then work your way right to a small ledge. Belay here. There’s a vertical crack 5 feet off the ledge for anchors. 

Pitch 2: Traverse far left about 15 to 20 feet across the horizontal cracks and then climb up the face to the top. This is the most photographed section of a climb at the Delaware Water Gap. Belay and rappel from the trees on top.

Noteable Variations:

 Triumvirate Direct - From mid-way up P2 as described, head left to gain an obvious large left facing corner and slabby face (potentially move the belay or end P1 here).  Follow this up till meeting a roof at the very end of the P3 traverse.  Place good gear and make an airy and committing swing around onto the face above the roof, rejoining P3 just below the cedar tree.  5.6.

 Descent:  A 180' double rope rappel from a bolted anchor, or continue 20' up 5.0 terrain to the very top.
content.protection: Pro is VERY good on this route, nice small chimney about 60' up, protect with a #8-#10 nut before climbing.
content.location: Very easy to see, mid-wall and look for the small chimney.

content.description:
Named after a legendary chief of the Lenni Lenape. This is a classic trad route at the Gap!

Pitch 1: Start at the base about 8 feet left of the big block with the tree on top. Climb over the vegetated sections to the blocked wall above. Climb up and left moving out onto a small face with an overhang below you. Climb up this face past the horizontal cracks onto another face up to a belay ledge with an old piton o the left.

Pitch 2: Climb up and left onto a small arete to the upper face staying left to the top. Belay and rappel from trees on top.
content.protection: 2 sets of nuts, small, medium and some 3"cams for the belay ledge. Try not to use the slings around the tree by the belay ledge or the lost arrow piton stuck in the wall.
content.location: Start 6' right of the oak tree below 'shadow line'.

content.description:
(Previously rated a 5.5 but upgraded to a 5.6) – This route has some great exposure so be cautious. 

Pitch 1: Start at the base where ‘Tanemund’ and ‘Triumverate’ start. Climb up and to the left past the small overgrown ledges to the leftmost prow passing over an overhang. Pass several overhangs and a small face with plenty of jugs if you look around. Climb to the small ledge, belay here. Pitch 2: Climb to an overhang and follow the large crack on the left to the top. Belay and rappel from the trees or walk to the ‘The Rib’ rappel bolts.
content.protection: Set of nuts, small to medium cams.
content.location: The exposed prow where the 'Black Wall' and the 'Triumverate Wall' meet.

content.description: The large block at the base of 'The Rib' offers several boulder problems. One specific faces the river on the West side. Climb the face toward the top of the bulge. Best top-roped as a fall with result in sliding down the hill.

Start at the right side base of the big block below the dihedral. (This route can be done in one pitch wit ha 70 meter rope). 

Pitch 1: Climb up the dihedral and work your way left onto a ledge just below a small face. Work your way up the face where there’s lots of anchors placements to a large ledge with 2 bolts about 3 feet off the ledge. Belay here. 

Pitch 2: Climb straight up the upper face into the dihedral staying left to the top. Belay and rappel from the trees or bolts on top of the cliff.
content.protection: Small nuts for start and large nuts, small to medium cams and some medium hexes for the rest of the route.

content.description:
Pitch 1: Start in the dihedral at the base of the block and to the right of ‘Triumverate’. Climb up the short dihedral onto the face past the ledge and work your way over into the upper dihedral. Stay in the corner for about 35 to 40 feet and then climb left just below the overhang. Belay here. 

Pitch 2: Climb up over the overhang (a 4 foot sling works well here to avoid rope drag) and onto the upper angled face. Continue past 2 horizontal cracks to the top. Belay and rappel from the trees or bolts on the far right side.
content.protection: Decent pro, remember a 4' sling for the large overhang. Someone left a red Metolius cam jammed mid-route here about 8 years ago and it still remains lodged.
content.location: Look for the large overhang and start on the ground below, the overhang is about 80'-90' up the wall.

content.description:
Start at the base to the left of the big block with the tree on top. 

Pitch 1: Climb straight up past the vegetated ledges to the face. Through the left-facing corners to the chimney above. Belay here. 

Pitch 2: Climb up and into the crux chimney to the top. Belay and rappel form the trees or bolts on the far right.
content.protection: Pro is good, but route gets airy and somewhat exposed towards the middle.
content.location: Just below the tiered ceilings next to 'Triumverate'

content.description: The most popular area on Mt Tammany, containing the two most accessible climbs on the cliff, The Rib, 5.3, and Triumvirate, 5.4.  There are many variations and linkups possible on the climbs on this wall, and many can easily be linked into long single pitches.  A standard Gunks rack is sufficient.  Many climbs end at (or can be ended at) a 2 bolt anchor on Triumvirate, just right of the obvious cedar 20' from the cliff top.  Descents: A double rope  rappel is required t orappel back to the gorund/baseline trail from the top of this cliff. You can accomplish some of the routes, like 'The Rib', with a 70 meter rope and 1 pitch but 2 ropes are needed for rappelling. If you gain access to the top of the cliff (lower  headwall), you can walk down the Class III slope and it eventually meets up with several old trails (grey & yellow), but they are no longer blazed and maintained. The were originally blazed by Hugh Dougher in the late 1970's and then reblazed by Joey Vulpis and Micky Levine in the early 2000's. Be cautious if hiking off from this section and it can be covered in scree.
